summary: the current influenza A H1N1 2009 virus pandemic, 1 the ongoing zoonotic transmission of influenza A H5N1 and the emergence of oseltamivirresistant seasonal influenza A H1N1 are threats to human health. hospital health care workers (HCWs) are key to effective pandemic response and the capacity of health care systems. a prospective, cluster randomized trial of medical mask and respirator use in frontline HCWs was conducted from December 2008 to January 2009 in Beijing, China. we initially aimed to determine the efficacy of two different kinds of respiratory protection (N95 respirators and medical masks) during the influenza season compared to each other and compared to a nomask group. the nine hospitals in the convenience noarm group were not part of the randomization. hospitals were selected from the same type of wards as the intervention arms. they were followed up in the same way as the trial participants. 1, 2 and 3, influenza viruses A and B, respiratory syncytial virus A and B, rhinovirus A/B and coronavirus OC43/HKU1 by multiplex PCR. the choice of a relatively broad CRI definition was dictated by our interest in interrupting transmission of a wide range of respiratory viruses. 3MTM FT30 Bitrex Fit Test kit according to manufacturers’ instructions (3MTM, St Paul, MN, USA) Detailed demographic and clinical details of all participants were collected. this included age, sex, smoking history, comorbidities, seasonal influenza vaccination status, medications, conduct of highrisk procedures. followup Participants were followed for 4 weeks of wearing the masks or respirators and an extra week of nonwearing for development of respiratory symptoms. two pharyngeal swabs were collected by a trained nurse or doctor. double rayontipped, plasticshafted swabs were used to scratch both tonsilar areas and the posterior pharyngeal wall. swabs were transported immediately after collection to the laboratory. oralen (8MOP) were added (8MOP, accompanied by UV irradiation for 20 minutes, prevents amplification of contaminated DNA. a mixture of 12 viral clones was used as a positive control template. sterile deionized water was used as a negative control. in the initial model, we included all the variables along with the main exposure variable those were significant (P 005) in the univariate analysis. we then used a backward elimination method to remove the variables that did not have any confounding effect. a prestudy assessment of hospital infection control levels determined that the hospitals had sufficient diversity to warrant stratified randomization by size of hospital and level of infection control. the assessment measured ventilation, spatial dimensions, bedding configuration, handwashing facilities and personal protective equipment use. intervention Participants wore the mask or respirator on every shift for 4 consecutive weeks. participants were shown when to wear it and how to fit it correctly. participants underwent fittesting procedure using a 3MTM FT30 Bitrex Fit Test kit. swabs of both tonsils and the posterior pharyngeal wall were collected. participants had two pharyngeal swabs collected by a trained nurse or doctor. multiplex polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was carried out using the Seeplex® RV12 Detection kit (Seegen, Inc., Seoul, Korea) to detect adenoviruses, human metapneumovirus, coronavirus 229E/NL63, parainfluenza viruses 1, 2 or 3, influenza viruses A or B, respiratory syncytial virus A or B and rhinovirus A/B. a random effect logistic regression model was used to estimate odds ratio. the model was fitted using ‘xtlogit’ command in stata (College Station, TX, USA) a sample size of 488 participants or five clusters per arm was required for cluster size (m) 100 and intracluster correlation coefficient (ICC) 001. as such, we aimed to recruit a sample size of 500 per arm. a total of 1441 nurses and doctors in 15 hospitals were recruited into the randomized arms. anyone smoking
